Which famous Hindu temples do not have a foundation?

There's one such very famous temple which has no foundation is Brihadeeswara temple dedicated to lord shiva located at Thanjavur. This temple is symbol of chola power and was built by Rajaraja chola in between 1003–1010 AD and was named as Rajarajeshwaram temple (The temple of iswara of Rajaraja). This site is also part of UNESCO world heritage site.

This temple made of granite has the tallest Vimana (tower) among temples in India with 16 storeys and height of more than 200ft. There's no binding material (such as plaster) used for construction. A masterpiece of architectural imagination where work was carried out on a grand scale with weight load evenly distributed among pillars and beams. On the top of this massive temple lies a shikhara (dome) of around 90tonnes weight. There's an interesting story behind placing this heavy shikhara on the top of temple tower. A 4km long incline path was bulit to enable it to be rolled over to the top of temple, later the path was dismantled.

There might be other temples without foundation but sadly I'm not much aware about them.

What are some Hindu temples in Pakistan?

Modern day Pakistan was home of Hinduism before arrival of Buddhism and Islam. Hinduism was integral part of Gandhara/Indus Civilization and flourished very well. Even though modern day Pakistan had Muslim majority before partition, still there are many sacred Hindu places which attracts many visitors across the globe. I will cover some of them.

Hinglaj Mata Temple (Balochistan):

Hinglaj Mata temple considered as one of the oldest Hindu temple in Pakistan. According to Hinduism, It is one of the Shakti Peethas of Goddess Sati. It is located in Lasbela District in Makran, Balochistan. Before part

Modern day Pakistan was home of Hinduism before arrival of Buddhism and Islam. Hinduism was integral part of Gandhara/Indus Civilization and flourished very well. Even though modern day Pakistan had Muslim majority before partition, still there are many sacred Hindu places which attracts many visitors across the globe. I will cover some of them.

Hinglaj Mata Temple (Balochistan):

Hinglaj Mata temple considered as one of the oldest Hindu temple in Pakistan. According to Hinduism, It is one of the Shakti Peethas of Goddess Sati. It is located in Lasbela District in Makran, Balochistan. Before partition of India, many Hindus across the India used to come but due to visa restrictions, only Hindus in Pakistan visits there.

Tilla Jogian (Jehlum, Punjab)

Tilla Jogian another abandoned Temple in Jehlum, Punjab (Pakistan). Before partition of India, it was one of the most visit site. It has now lost its significance and I scare this place might get vanish in coming decades.

Katas Raj Temples:

Katas Raj Temples are group of several temples which are at bank of Katas pond. According to Hinduism, Katas pond is eye drop of Lord Shiva at the death of his wife Sati. This temple is in good shape and many Hindus across the globe still visits here. This is considered as one of the holiest and sacred place for Hindus in Pakistan. Govt of Pakistan is paying much attention to preserve this site in best possible manner.

Saidpur Village:

Saidpur Village is situated near Daman e Koh Islamabad. This village is famous to have , Mandir and Gurdwara at one place.

Saidpur Hindu Temple:

Saidpur Gurdwara:

The govt of Pakistan did their best effort and restored these sites to their original state.

Temples in Rawalpindi:

My home city Rawalpindi had one of the largest Hindu community before the partition of India. It was probably the only city in modern day Pakistan (alongwith Karachi) with slight Hindu and Sikh majority. I can safely assume there are still many temples in old Rawalpindi than any other city of Pakistan. But due to mass migration of Hindus at the time of 1947, all of these temples are closed. Despite 70 years, you can still count there are as many temples in Rawalpindi than Mosques in the pictures.

Kalyan Das Temple (Rawalpindi)

Temple near Chittian Hattian Rawalpindi:

Bagh Sardaran Hindu Temples (Rawalpindi)

Krishna Mandir Saddar: (The only active Mandir in Rawalpindi)

We cannot deny the cultural legacy of Hinduism in Pakistan and we all Pakistanis should play our important part to preserves these sites.

What is the most popular Hindu temple in the world?

The most popular Hindu temple in the world is the ancient Venkateshwara Balaji Temple on the peak of Venkatadri Hill among the seven sacred hills of Tirumala at Tirupati, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India. It attracts 30,000 to 100,000 visitors per day, just on normal days throughout the year, not even counting big festivals (during which it may hit 500,000). Including festivals, it has 30 to 40 million visitors per year. It provides free meals to all of them. This makes it not only the most popular Hindu temple, but the most popular holy site of any religion in the world.

The temple is dedicated to Venkateshwara, a form of Vishnu also known as Balaji, Srinivasa, and Govinda. This local manifestation is specifically to provide salvation during the trying times of Kaliyuga, hence its immense popularity in this present age.

Do Buddhists visit Hindu temples?

Some Buddhists visit Hindu temples; others don’t. It’s a common practice in Sri Lanka. I talked to many Buddhists there about various spiritual topics, and they told me that it’s the norm for Sri Lankan Buddhists to visit Hindu temples, even doing their main annual pilgrimages to a Hindu temple (Kataragama). I myself visited multiple joint Buddhist-Hindu temple complexes where visitors, Buddhist and Hindu alike, went from shrine to shrine, praying or meditating at both the Buddhist and Hindu shrines. This is very much commonplace in Sri Lanka.

It’s also common in Nepal, where a large portion of

Some Buddhists visit Hindu temples; others don’t. It’s a common practice in Sri Lanka. I talked to many Buddhists there about various spiritual topics, and they told me that it’s the norm for Sri Lankan Buddhists to visit Hindu temples, even doing their main annual pilgrimages to a Hindu temple (Kataragama). I myself visited multiple joint Buddhist-Hindu temple complexes where visitors, Buddhist and Hindu alike, went from shrine to shrine, praying or meditating at both the Buddhist and Hindu shrines. This is very much commonplace in Sri Lanka.

It’s also common in Nepal, where a large portion of the population identifies as both Hindu and Buddhist, and consider them to be one religion, not two. They visit each other’s temples without discrimination all the time.

There are joint Hindu-Buddhist sites like this in India too, from Gaya to Sarnath and other smaller ones in villages here and there.

Many Buddhists live in countries where Hindu temples are rare so of course they don’t visit them.

Which is the oldest Hindu temple which still exists?

The Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

This temple is located in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India. Kanchi Kailasanathar is a Hindu temple in the Dravidian architectural style. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its historical importance. The temple was built from 685-705 AD by a Rajasimha ruler of the Pallava Dynasty.

It is one of the earliest structural temples and the largest one built by the Pallavas.

The Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

This temple is located in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu, India. Kanchi Kailasanathar is a Hindu temple in the Dravidian architectural style. It is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its historical importance. The temple was built from 685-705 AD by a Rajasimha ruler of the Pallava Dynasty.

It is one of the earliest structural temples and the largest one built by the Pallavas.

It is of stone-built architecture unlike the rock-cut architecture built into hallowed caves or carved into rock outcrops as in Mahabalipuram. The tall gopuram (tower) is to the left and the temple complex is to the right. The temple's foundations are made of granite, which could withstand the weight of the temple, while the superstructure, including the carvings, are all made of sandstone.

Facts About Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple

  1. The most famous Brihadeshwara Temple in Thanjavur is inspired by Kailasanathar Temple.
  2. A passage is there inside the shrine. One has to crawl inside the passage and climb several steps to reach the exit. It is believed that this passage is symbolic of life and death.

Kanchipuram, one of India’s oldest continuously inhabited cities is often called the land of a thousand temples, and beautiful temples are the crowning glory of the magnificent city. If you are visiting Chennai don’t miss this.

Tips for the Temple visit

  • It is around 70 kilometres from Chennai.
  • Temple is open from 6 AM -12 PM and then 4 PM-9 PM
  • It is a very photogenic temple. Thankfully photography is permitted, except inside the sanctum.

Thank you for reading!

According to me Kanchi Kamakshi Amman temple is the main historically important temple famous all over the world!!

Below is the picture of Goddess Kamakshi Amman who is the mother of this entire universe!

Kamakshi Amman Temple, Kanchipuram – History

The Kamakshi Amman Temple was built by the Pallava Kings to glorify the Hindu religion. After being built in the 7th century A.D., the temple was again renovated during the 14th by the Cholas. As per archaeological evidence, Kanchipuram has been a hub of Paleolithic, Mesolithic and Neolithic settlements. Numerous temples have been excavated from the area and Kanchipuram is also popularly known as the City of Thousand Temples. The Vaishnavite Tiruvekka or the Yathokthakari Temple was the first temple mentioned in literary references. The temples of Kanchipuram are widely believed to uphold the glorious history of this region.

Kanchipuram has been the capital city of Pallava kings. The main deity, Kamakshi Ambal is seated in a majestic Padmasana posture signifying peace, tranquility and prosperity. The goddess holds a sugarcane bow and bunch of flowers in the lower two of her arms and has a pasha (rope), an ankusha (goading weapon) in her upper two arms. There is also a parrot perched near the flower bunch. Surprisingly this is the only temple for Goddess Parvathi in the city of Kanchipuram. The original Kamakshi Devi Temple is what is presently known as Adi Peeteswari or the Adi Peeta Parameswari. This temple is adjacent to the Kumarakottam and is near to the presently famous Kamakshi Devi temple.

Kanchi Kamatchi Temple, or Kamakshi Amman Temple, Kanchipuram (Kancheepuram) is the abode of Parvathi, Lord Shiva’s wife. Fearing the wicked Asuras (demons) the Devas (gods) came here and lived as parrots in the Champaka tree and prayed to Devi to free them from the terror of the asuras. She appeared, through the secret passage called Pilakasam, in Kanchi to slay Bhandakasuran and the other demons who were troubling the Devas.

Since then, Kamakshi Amman resides is in this great shrine in the center of the Gayathri Mandapam, that is said to have been built by the Devas for her. She is a swayambu (self-manifested) deity in this temple. The city is linked to her name as Kanchi Kamakshi.

Adi Shankaracharya is closely associated with the rich history of Kanchi Kamatchi Temple. The original form of Kamakshi was less benign than how she is represented today.

Animal and human sacrifices were part of rituals in ancient Shakthi temples. Adi Shankaracharya led a movement to banish this aspect of Hindu worship, brought back vegetarianism and in this temple, introduced the benign and peaceful representation of the goddess by placing a divine Chakra (sacred instrument) in front of the deity.

Symbolic of this connection with Adi Shankaracharya, during festivals when the processional deity is taken out around the temple streets, she first takes leave of Shankaracharya in his shrine in the inner corridor. It is also believed that Shankaracharya defeated Buddhist and other philosophers in this place, sparking a revival of Hinduism. Local folklore relates this incident and also says that other forms of Shakthi outside Kanchipuram continue to reveal the fierce forms of Shakthi.

Where is the largest Hindu temple, and in which state or country?

The largest Hindu temple is Angkor Wat at Angkor, Cambodia. It is not only the largest Hindu temple but the largest monument of any religion in the world, covering 402 acres. However it is no longer an ‘active’ Hindu temple with priests performing the rituals there, but mostly a ruin in the jungles.

The largest active, functioning Hindu temple is the Sri Ranganathasvamy Temple in Tiruchirapalli, Tamil Nadu, India.

In terms of largest number of pilgrims, donations, etc. (rather than physical size), the largest Hindu temple is the Venkateswara Temple at Tirumala, Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh, India. It is the most-visited holy place in the world, of any religion.

What makes certain Hindu temple very popular?

As many Hindus become more religious and decide to visit temples more often, this is a question I have been asking to myself for a long time.

For example, right now the Sabarimala temple is an extremely popular place of worship in Kerala. But this was not always the case. Apparently during my grandmother’s generation, there weren’t many people who wanted to visit this temple.

Similarity the Attukal Pongala - an event that pays homage to Attukal Devi in Thiruvananthapuram is gaining popularity. Earlier the dish (which is prepared in a mud pot with fire supported from bricks) was made only in the

As many Hindus become more religious and decide to visit temples more often, this is a question I have been asking to myself for a long time.

For example, right now the Sabarimala temple is an extremely popular place of worship in Kerala. But this was not always the case. Apparently during my grandmother’s generation, there weren’t many people who wanted to visit this temple.

Similarity the Attukal Pongala - an event that pays homage to Attukal Devi in Thiruvananthapuram is gaining popularity. Earlier the dish (which is prepared in a mud pot with fire supported from bricks) was made only in the temple premises. Later as more women started doing it, some roads near the temple had to be occupied. But now a large section of the city is blocked on the day of Pongala for the event to take place! Even in the North, there is an increasing spirit among people who wants a Ram Mandir to be created in Ayodhya.

So what makes certain temples (like the ones at Thirupathy or Sabarimala) more famous?

To me personally it looks like a word of mouth popularity. For instance, right from childhood, I have been hearing of Guruvayur temple, Rameshwaram temple, Thirupathy temple - all because I have heard these from my other family members.

Why do they visit these places? It’s probably because that they believe that they will ‘be blessed’ by the deity residing in these temples when they visit them.

Other reasons (why some other people visit temples, though majority just visit after hearing about it and not after doing some research on the historical significance of the temple)

  1. Size of the temple - Some temples like Madurai Meenakshi temple is famous beacuse it is so huge with large and beautiful gopuras
  2. Wealth of the temple - Padmanabhaswamy temple is famous as it is one of the wealthiest places of worship in the world
  3. Religious significance- Temples like Krishnajanmabhoomi temple is famous because it is believed to be the birth place of Krishna.
  4. Timeline significance- Some temples are significant because of their old age. For example the Puri Jagannath temple was built in the 12th century - which is 900 years ago.
  5. Structural significance - The Kailasa temple in Maharashtra has the significance of being cut from a single large stone right in the 8th century!
  6. Multiple combination of above- The Nataraja temple in Chidambaram is huge, structurally beautiful and was built in the 10th century.

What kind of worship is this?

I have always wondered at what form of worship this this - stand in a queue for a long time to see some idol for a couple of seconds and an offering by the priest.

Personally I don’t have a great experience in visiting many temples. For example, consider the example of vising the famous Thirupathy temple. We had to remove our sandals and leave out cell phones in our car or some counter near the temple. Then walk barefoot which as such was not very appealing as the floor wasn’t clean enough . The crowd was huge and we had to wait for hours. Apart from that once we got in front of the deity, there was a huge push. For a couple of seconds, I couldn’t see my family and was scared! I felt lost as I had no cell phone to contact them! After everything was done, I was just relieved to start back home.

The idea of leaving a cell phone behind is so dangerous in a country like India where women are kidnapped and trafficked. I have made up my mind that as much as I can, I will refrain from places where I am not allowed to carry a cell phone. If the idea of banning cell phones is to prevent ringtone noises and flash photography, why not write that message and impose a fine on people who don’t obey it?

Is this the only form of worship available?

I have been reading Puranas right from childhood and from what I understand, the ultimate form of worship is following the path of righteousness. Apart from that there are incidents were sages and demons themselves meditate to attain some boon from the Gods. But the idea of some intermediate person praying something to God for the sake of someone else is not found in these places. (There are sages who do yagnas- but that is for the kingdom as whole. And anyone can become a sage.)

Why would I want to visit a temple?

Personally I want to visit a temple to

  1. Admire the architectural beauty of it. The carvings and sculpture work is astounding.
  2. Have a spiritual experience - Now this would have been possible had the temple premises be neat, calm and quiet with light devotional music being played in the background. In that case, it would be possible to sit in a corner and have a sense of satisfaction. But in most of the actual visits, the atmosphere is noisy and the surrounding premises are dirty with ghee, water, flowers and sand. I have to wash my feet more carefully when I visit a temple than any other place. Plus having a cell phone would be a relief as I could use it to contact if needed. Also taking pics is a good way to preserve memories.

What do majority Hindu practices look like to me?

Hinduism as practiced by many people just looks a mixture of discriminatory practices (like the caste systems), ridiculous rituals and superstitions like astrology. But all this is far from away from the philosophical teachings of Hinduism. I was wondering about these contrasts when i came across the Arya Samaj and it’s founder Dayananda Saraswati. It is indeed impressive that right in the 1800s, a person was able to point out all this superstitions and ridiculous practices in the religion. But what is shocking is that ‘conventional temples’ are far more popular than Arya Samaj establishments. Is it because of marketing skill? For instance, the first time I even heard of Arya Samaj was when I was reading about how actress Nayanthara embraced Hinduism! Whereas I constantly hear of ‘conventional’ temples from family and friends.

When it comes to religious practices, we blindly follow what our previous generation did without exploring other options.

How many Hindus are aware that Hindu philosophies include options like atheism and agnostic views? In fact, I am agnostic myself. However once I started reading about it in the internet, I was really impressed to find that Hinduism is the only religion that includes agnostic views among its philosophies!

What is the service of a Hindu temple?

I’m assuming you mean “service” in the sense of public ceremonial worship, the way it’s used in Christianity, though I’ve never heard the term used that way by Hindus. There are usually no sermons or talks by a priest.

It can vary widely from temple to temple and even from day to day within a temple. The most common form of worship in most Hindu temples is Puja. The priest(s) perform Puja several times throughout the day at specific times. It generally involves ringing bells, passing a flame before the Murtis (ritually enlivened idols) of the Gods, chanting mantras, making offerings (mainly of water and certain foods) and performing various other ritual actions. Worshippers may come to give thanks to the Divine, to ask for assistance, to perform penance, to contemplate; but most of all to experience the Darshan of the Gods.

Darshan literally means sight, but it conveys much more. The worshipper makes eye contact with the deity, and intensely feels the deity seeing them back, like eye contact with a living person. In Darshan, one imbibes the energy of the deity and receives blessings. It doesn’t even strictly require eye contact; blind Hindus still speak of “getting Darshan”, for example. It’s just a close, intimate communion with the deity.

The priest mainly assists by fully waking the Murtis and calling their attention so that worshippers may come and have their Darshan. Most offerings are also made by the priest, since technical methods and purity requirements usually apply.

Sometimes individuals or family groups have specific rituals performed for them at Hindu temples. There is a huge variety of such rituals. Also, special Pujas occur on specific days, and festivities happen in Hindu temples on the great festival days. There are also other, more elaborate rituals, such as Homas (also called Yagnyas or Havanas), involving large fire sacrifices. Usually fewer people are allowed to attend these.

Essentially Hindu temples serve as dwelling places for deities, so that worshippers may come and worship them there with the aid of specialists.

What is the history behind why Hindu temples were built?

Hinduism is one of the oldest surviving religion in the world . The wide time frame and large number of followers, create the need for better worship places , temples which act on various levels.

In some places a temple is more associated with the local administration of a region and kingdoms and regional landlords use the temple its trust as well as the infrastructure for solving local issues and gathering the people for discussions, announcements and other auspicious occasions.

In other situations temples play a huge role in education. the base of education in ancient times was religious learn

Hinduism is one of the oldest surviving religion in the world . The wide time frame and large number of followers, create the need for better worship places , temples which act on various levels.

In some places a temple is more associated with the local administration of a region and kingdoms and regional landlords use the temple its trust as well as the infrastructure for solving local issues and gathering the people for discussions, announcements and other auspicious occasions.

In other situations temples play a huge role in education. the base of education in ancient times was religious learning before the children were taught about scientific subjects like mathematics , commerce etc, they all began at the grass root level from temples with the temple administration and the priest becoming the first teachers to the society.

Hindu temples also were relevant for the financial set up of older kingdoms were the temples were specifically designed to store treasures , cash and other relevant articles safely . The huge amount of wealth seen in our ancient temple cellars is a perfect example for the kings using temples as part of the government missionary

During the chola period temples in south India also were used as courts for solving judicial issues disputes between citizens .

All the reasons point towards the relevance of temples and the need to build them

What are some famous Hindu temples in your home country or home state?

Since, the whole state is concerned, the answer is going to be a long one, kindly bear with it.

So my home state is WEST BENGAL, India, where you will find a temple at an interval of every 1 km. In such a situation it is very difficult to choose, still I have tried my best to provide with a good trivia.

KOLKATA:

Dakshineswar Mandir : This temple is dedicated to Goddess Kali. Located on the banks of River Hoogly, this “siddhapith” was built by Rani Raashmoni, when by traditional accounts, Goddess Kali instructed her in dreams to build a temple rather than going to pilgrimage in Benaras.

Birla Templ

Since, the whole state is concerned, the answer is going to be a long one, kindly bear with it.

So my home state is WEST BENGAL, India, where you will find a temple at an interval of every 1 km. In such a situation it is very difficult to choose, still I have tried my best to provide with a good trivia.

KOLKATA:

Dakshineswar Mandir : This temple is dedicated to Goddess Kali. Located on the banks of River Hoogly, this “siddhapith” was built by Rani Raashmoni, when by traditional accounts, Goddess Kali instructed her in dreams to build a temple rather than going to pilgrimage in Benaras.

Birla Temple : The main temple houses deities of Lord Krishna and Devi Radha. It is built of white marble bearing resemblances to Lingaraj Temple of Bhubaneswar.

Adhyapeeth : This three-peaked temple is dedicated to Maa Adya. This is renowned pilgrimage in Kolkata. It was built by Sree Ananda Thakur when he, in his dream, was advised by Devi Adya to construct such a temple to teach human beings dictums of love and idealism.

Thanthania Kali Bari : Dedicated to Devi Siddheswari, a form of Devi Kali, this temple was built by Shankar Ghosh around 300 years ago. The idol, even older than the temple, is made up of clay and painted with red and black every year.

HOWRAH:

Belur Math : Well this is not a typical Hindu temple where Gods or Goddesses are worshipped. It houses temples dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, Sri Ramakrishna and Maa Sharada in which their relics are enshrined. It uniqueness lies in the fact that its architecture that amalgamates Christian, Hindu, Islamic and Buddisht art motifs as a symbol of unity.

MAYAPUR:

ISKCON Mandir : This temple is dedicated to Lord Krishna in specific. However one will find numerous other shrines of dedicated devotees of Lord Krishna. The campus is just beautiful and soothing. One of major spiritual pilgrimage centres of the followers of Santana Dharma, this place will usurp your worries and give you solace by its very ambience.

NABADWIP: This is the birth place of Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, one of the greatest devotees Lord Krishna. Thus this place has numerous temples, maths and ashrams associated with him and Lord Krishna.

Sonar Gourango Mandir : This temple is famous for the golden shrine and idol of Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu.

Sri Chaitanya Saraswat Math : Founded by the followers of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, this temple is dedicated to the holy soul.

Shri Devananda Gaudiya Math : There are five deities worshipped in this “math” one of them being Sri Gourango. The five deities preside in five chambers and samadhi mandir.

Radha Rani Mandir : This temple is dedicated to Devi Radha and symbolises her love for Lord Krishna. Another folklore surrounding the place narrates that the temple has appeared on its own.

Narahari Dham Ashram : This place has a 60 feet long idol of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu which is one of the biggest idols ever made. This temple was built at a site where it is believed that Sri Chaitanya Dev met Thakur Narhari, one of his great disciples.

HOOGHLY:

Hangseshwari Mandir : This temple is dedicated to Goddess Hangseshwari, worshipped as a form of Devi Kali. It was built by Raja Nrisingha Deb Roy after he believed that Goddess herself came in his dream. It has a distinctive architecture unique from the usual pattern present in that area, consisting 13 minars or Ratnas, each built as a blooming lotus bud.

BIRBHUM:

Tarapeeth : This temple is dedicated to Goddess Tara, a fearsome Tantric aspect of Devi Shakti. This temple is widely renowned for its Tantric facet and the adjoining cremation ground where “Tantric Sadhna” is performed by saints. Sadhak Byamakhepa, a dedicated devotee of Devi Tara, spent his entire life in Tarapeeth doing sadhana.

BANKURA:

Siddheswara Mandir : Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this temple is known for its intricate carvings on the walls and the Kalinga style of architecture it is built in. It is an ancient brick temple having Rekha-Deul style of architecture.

PURULIA:

Deulghata : It houses many ancient brick temples. Most have been ruined and dilapidated over the years, however, still there are three large temples with intricate stucco decoration on brick. First temple is 60 feet tall with floral designs and Hindu and Jain symbols on the wall. Second temple is almost similar to the first one along with a small image of Lord Ganesh inside and images of deities from Nepali Hindu paintings. The third one is in a bad shape. This place also as an age old idol of Devi Durga.

BISHNUPUR: As the name suggests, this place is filled with temples dedicated to Lord Vishnu. This place is widely renowned for its terracotta temples built by the Mallya rulers between 1700–1800.

Jor Bangla Mandir : Built in classic chala-style architecture that originated in West Bengal, this temple has wonderful work of intricate terracotta carvings on its walls. The twin temples are built in village hut style joined by a single pillar.

Rasmancha Mandir : It is the oldest brick temple of Bishnupur. It has pyramidal terracotta type architecture enshrining Radha-Krishna.

Lalji Mandir : Constructed in EkaRatna style of architecture, this temple enshrines Lord Krishna. It also has ornamental stucco decorations on low relief carvings.

Pancha Ratna Mandir : Dedicated to Lord Krishna, this temple also has amazing terracotta carvings on its walls depicting life of its deity.

Malleshwar Mandir : It is an EkaRatna temple built of laterite stone built in Rekha-Deul style. It is probably the only temple in Bishnupur that is dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Radhabinode Mandir : It is also known as navaratna temple as it has nine turrets. The temple has terracotta carvings and an ancient architecture.

Madan Mohan Mandir : Made up of brick with terracotta tablets cladding the walls, portico and pillars of the temple, this is dedicated to Lord Krishna. Impressive wall carvings depicts events from Ramayana, Mahabharata and Puranas.

Radha Shyam Mandir : Built in EkaRatna style, it is dedicated to Radha-Krishna. It has stucco motifs depicting floral and geometric designs and life from the Puranas.

SHAKTI PEETH: This temples have mythological reference to its origin. It is believed that the corpse of Devi Sati was cut into 51 parts by Lord Vishnu with his “Sudarshan Chakra” when Lord Shiva was grieving with anguish on the death of Devi Sati. Thus 51 parts fell on earth and became sacred sites of pilgrimage after they were enshrined.

Kalighat Kali Mandir, Kolkata : Enshrining Goddess Kali, it represents the place where the toes of the right foot of Devi Sati fell during Rudra Tandav.

Nandikeshwari Mandir, Birbhum : This temple enshrines a black stone, as Devi Nandikeshwari which is adorned with a silver crown and three golden eyes. It is believed that the necklace of Devi Sati fell here.

Kankaleshwari Mandir, Birbhum : It is believed that the waist of Devi Sati's corpse fell here. Here the Shakti is addressed as “Devgarbha” and Rudra and Bhairava as “Ruru”.

Nalhateshwari Mandir, Birbhum : Situated atop a small hill, it is dedicated to Devi Kali. This temple enshrined the site where the throat of Devi Sati fell.

Kiriteshwari Temple, Murshidabad : It is the oldest temple in Murshidabad believed to have been constructed around 1000 years ago or more. It is dedicated to Kiriteshwari Devi, also called ‘Vimala’. It was believed to be the sleeping place of Devi Mahamaya. The deity is also called ‘Mukuteshwari' as it is believed that the crown of Devi Sati fell here.

Fullara Mandir, Birbhum : It is believed lower lip of Devi Sati fell here. There is no idol or image of Devi Sati but a large stone is worshipped as the embodiment of the Goddess.

BAKRESWAR: Besides being reverend for the temple, this place is also known for ten hit springs it houses. It is believed to have been built where forehead of Goddess Sati fell. These temples are dedicated to Bakranath (Lord Shiva) and Devi Sati. It is also one of the Shakti Peeth. It has the following temples: Maa Bhavatarini Mandir, Bakreswar Mandir, Mahisasur Mardini Mandir and Bhairabnath Mandir.

FAMOUS SHIVA TEMPLES:

Taraknath Mandir, Tarakeshwar : This temple built, in atchala structure of Bengali temple architecture, around swayambhu linga, is dedicated to Lord Taraknath (Shiva) and is a major pilgrimage site of West Bengal. The temple campus also has a “dudhpukur” where devotees take a dip.

Mahakal Mandir, Darjeeling : The main temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is constructed atop the Observatory Hill and is a pilgrimage site for both Hindus and Buddhists alike. There are three gold plated lingams inside the main temple representing the Hindu triumvirate Brahma, Vishnu and Maheswar.

Kalyaneshwar Mandir, Bally : Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this 500 years old temple is believed to have been started by Pandavas and it was then continued by the Katoch dynasty. It is a very famous temple visited by millions of monks and pilgrims every year during Shivratri.

Kashishwar Jiu Mandir, Howrah : Built near the Saraswati River, this temple enshrines a ‘banlinga’ believed to have been recovered from the river in 17th century by a local zamindar Kashishwar Datta Chowdhury. In 18th century, a stone made ‘yoni’ like structure resembling ‘Shakti’ was attached to the linga.

KAMARPUKUR :

It is the birthplace of Sri Ramakrishna and his birthplace has been constructed into a math or temple campus. Thousands of followers visit this pilgrimage site in search of solace and salvation.

JAYRAMBATI :

It is the birthplace of Maa Sharada and she is widely venerated and her birthplace which has been constructed into a “math” draws thousands of pilgrims to this place.

*I have not visited each one of these pilgrimage sites personally. So there might be some ambiguity or mismatch regarding the temples and their corresponding pictures. If so, please recommend the rectification.*

Did Hindu kings destroy temples?

Not like Arabic/Persian Invaders.

Arabic and Persian Invaders plundered and destroyed all the temples and looted the money while Hindu rulers plundered only the treasure in Palaces/Forts and destroyed only palaces and forts and cities but not temples .

But Hindu Kings used to Bring the Murthy of Gods and some sculptures without any damage from the defeated Kingdoms and installed the same in their Kingdom to prove the victory in front of the Kingdom subjects or to showcase the victory for ages to come!

Unlike Islam rulers who used the sculptures for other purposes but that's not the case of Hindu Kings.

Reinstalling Vigrahams or Murthies in some other place without destroying it is not considered as sin in Hinduism and even the plundered wealth of other kingdoms were used to construct the new temples!

This has happened in many instances.

Pallava Time

Pallavas were ruling from Kanchi which is now in Tamil Nadu and Pallavas were one of the strongest ruling kingdoms of that time who were known for their temple architecture and the famous Kings.


> Vatapi Ganapathi( Badami as called now in Karnataka) which is in Tamil Nadu now , is believed to have been abducted from Vatapi and brought to the Tamil region by Paranjothi, a general in the army of the enemy Pallava king during one of the many battles fought between Chalukya and Pallava armies in the 7th century CE.

The icon is said to have been reinstalled in a small shrine in the Uthrapathisvaraswami temple complex in Tamil Nadu, later the same Paranjyothi becomes as Nayanmar or a Shaiva Saint.

The games Sanskrit sing “Vatapi Ganapathim" is composed praising the same Ganapthi my Muthuswami Dikshitar who lived and composed several centuries later in 18th century.

Now Narasimhavaraman in return constructs a Mallikarjuna temple at Vatapi with the same bounty to commemorate his victory, and took the title ‘Vatapi-Kondan’ or ‘taker of Vatapi’.

But some historians say this is myth , am not sure

Rich slice of history [ https://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/history-and-culture/rich-slice-of-history/article4533954.ece ]


Now let's go to same Chalukya Time-Chalukyas of Badami

Aihole near Badami has a Kailasanathar temple.

This temple resembles the kailasanathar temple of Kanchi. After defeating Pallavas, Vikramaditya Pulikesi took both his queens to Kanchipuram. They visited the Kailasanathar temple and wanted to construct a similar one in their town. The treasures from Kanchi were used to build the Kailasanathar temple of Aihole.

There are also 2 temples, names Lokeshwara temple and Trilokeshwara temple. Based on their wives names, lokamadevi (Lokeshwara) and Trilokadevi(Trilokeshwara).

Why have famous Hindu temples become marketplaces?

In India temples were built with a larger purpose than to just be a place of worship.

They functioned as schools and in many places still do. I believe the correct term would be Ved Patashala. Kids from all the nearby localities were sent to learn and gain knowledge. They were places of social gatherings on auspicious occasions and festivals, as a means for Kings to showcase their prosperity, a place that offers solace for the old and the poor.

Most importantly they were the primary means of encouraging art and architecture. Ever seen a temple without painting or sculptures? Temple building in ancient India provided employment to artisans who would otherwise have no viable source of income. Building a temple took decades.

The temples feel over-populated because they indeed are over-populated. The population of India when these temples were built was hardly a thousandth of what it is today. This case is not limited to just temples. Been to a railway station in 1980s? Now visit a railway station in any metropolitan city. Granted a temple and a railway station may not be same. But you get the picture.

In olden days, kings donated insane amounts of gold and wealth to temples. Rich guys who had no children to inherit their wealth bequeathed it to the temples. All this wealth was in turn used by the temple to feed the poor, keep the temple premises clean, pay for the priests’ livelihood, carry out repairs to the temple, for temple festivals and so on.

There are no kings now, the government won’t donate money to temples and the rich guys nowadays are more concerned with amassing more wealth. Donating to temples would be last on their list. So how will the priests’ family survive, what will they eat, who will pay for the repairs, who will keep the temple clean (People do litter the temple premises and carve their names Michelangelo style), who will pay for all the expenses incurred during festival time, the electricity bill, the water bill, charity and all the other stuff?

The reason it feels unpeaceful is because internally the person is in turmoil - societal pressure, peer pressure, familial problems. They simply expect too much from a temple. Temple is not a magical world of Narnia wherein you enter and all your sorrow magically disappears.

There was one guy named Maharishi Ramana in Madurai, TamilNadu. When asked a question regarding the reason behind people seeking solitude to meditate he replied - “It is possible to feel alone and peaceful in a noisy crowd and burdened by baggage and distracted in middle of a secluded forest”. (The man’s exact words are different). Therefore bhakts have nothing to do about it.

Just have faith in whatever god you worship, focus and will your problems to melt away and your visit to the temple will have accomplished its purpose.

Answered your question I have.

What are some popular temples in India?

The most popular temple in India is Tirupati Balaji Temple in Tirumala, Andhra Pradesh, with 30 to 40 million pilgrims per year. I wrote this answer about it:

Devala Rees
· Nov 30
What is the most popular Hindu temple in the world?
The most popular Hindu temple in the world is the ancient Venkateshwara Balaji Temple on the peak of Venkatadri Hill among the seven sacred hills of Tirumala at Tirupati, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India. It attracts 30,000 to 100,000 visitors per day, just on normal days throughout the year, not even counting big festivals (during which it may hit 500,000). Including festivals, it has 30 to 40 million visitors per year. It provides free meals to all of them. This makes it not only the most popular Hindu temple, but the most popular holy site of any religion in the world. The temple is dedicated to Venkateshwara, a form of Vishnu also known as Balaji, Srinivasa, and Govinda. This local manifestation is specifically to provide salvation during the trying times of Kaliyuga, hence its immense popularity in this present age.

The second-most popular temple in India is Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, with 22 million pilgrims per year. It is the main temple of the city of Kashi, also called Varanasi, the spiritual capital of India and a strong candidate for the oldest continuously inhabited city on Earth. It is the most revered of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples, the main temples to Shiva, all twelve of which

What is the most popular Hindu temple in the world?
The most popular Hindu temple in the world is the ancient Venkateshwara Balaji Temple on the peak of Venkatadri Hill among the seven sacred hills of Tirumala at Tirupati, Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, India. It attracts 30,000 to 100,000 visitors per day, just on normal days throughout the year, not even counting big festivals (during which it may hit 500,000). Including festivals, it has 30 to 40 million visitors per year. It provides free meals to all of them. This makes it not only the most popular Hindu temple, but the most popular holy site of any religion in the world. The temple is dedicated to Venkateshwara, a form of Vishnu also known as Balaji, Srinivasa, and Govinda. This local manifestation is specifically to provide salvation during the trying times of Kaliyuga, hence its immense popularity in this present age.

The second-most popular temple in India is Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh, with 22 million pilgrims per year. It is the main temple of the city of Kashi, also called Varanasi, the spiritual capital of India and a strong candidate for the oldest continuously inhabited city on Earth. It is the most revered of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples, the main temples to Shiva, all twelve of which could well be included in a list like this one. I wrote this answer about its tragic history:

Devala Rees
· 8mo
How many times has the Kashi Vishwanath Temple been destroyed and rebuilt?
Essentially it has been destroyed four times and rebuilt five, though not all in exactly the same location or with the same name. The original temple was called the Vishweshwara Temple. It was destroyed in 1194 by the order of Qutbud-din Aibak, and the Razia Mosque was later built over it. In the late 1200s, the replacement temple had been rebuilt in the Avimukteshwara temple compound. It was destroyed again by the Sharqi kings of Jaunpur sometime between 1435 and 1458. It was soon rebuilt, then destroyed again in the 1490s by Sikandar Lodhi. Then by the patronage of Raghunath Pandit of Kashi, the new Vishweshwara Temple was rebuilt in 1585. It was destroyed yet again by the order of Aurangzeb in 1669, and the Gyanvapi Mosque was built over it, incorporating part of the original structure in a deliberately visibly obvious fashion: Then the Maratha ruler Ahilya Bai Holkar of Indore built the new Kashi Vishwanath Temple in 1780, on a new site, as the mosques still stood over the original sites. By then Muslim rule of India was waning and they were mostly past their temple-destroying days, and sure enough, no one else came to destroy it. The pattern here is abundantly clear.

The third-most popular temple in India is Vaishno Devi Temple, with over 10 million pilgrims per year. This temple is nestled on the Trikuta mountain near Katra in Jammu, marking the spot where the woman Vaishno Devi, considered a Divine incarnation, killed a powerful man who was trying to rape her. I wrote this answer about it:

Devala Rees
· Dec 16
What makes Vaishno Devi such a popular pilgrimage site in India? What aspects of the site distinguish it from other pilgrimage destinations?
This is an interesting question to me, and one whose implications go beyond just Vaishno Devi. India is full of thousands of pilgrimage sites. Their popularity ranges all over the place. Vaishno Devi is the third most popular, with over ten million visitors per year. On the opposite end, many pilgrimage sites are so obscure they’re unheard of by the vast majority of Indians, and only a few people go there, even if they find mention in some ancient scripture. Indeed some pilgrimage sites praised in ancient scriptures became so obscure that they were actually lost, and today no one is sure where exactly the site is that the scripture refers to! So, why are some so popular and others not? What aspects distinguish them from each other and determine their popularity? When an Indian person decides to go on a pilgrimage, how do they choose among the thousands of options? Here are some distinguishing aspects of Vaishno Devi: * Miracle stories flourish around Vaishno Devi. People say that their pilgrimage there restored the use of a crippled or withered limb, or cured their blindness or infertility, brought wealth and good fortune to the desperately poor, or even resurrected their dead baby. Of course such stories are not unique to this one pilgrimage, but even as a Hindu with no particular connection to Vaishno Devi (I’ve never been there, it’s not especially emphasized in my community, etc.), I have the impression that Vaishno Devi is exceptionally miracle-rich (or at least, it is widely claimed to be). I suspect this may be the one of the biggest factors right here. * A traditional answer to this whole question is that Mata Vaishno Devi helped Lord Rama win victory over Ravana, and that he blessed her that the entire world would sing her praises and revere her. So some say that it is Lord Rama’s boon that makes Vaishno Devi such a popular pilgrimage site. * Vaishno Devi is a very ancient pilgrimage site, with the temple already mentioned in the Mahabharata. While this is far from unique - many pilgrimage sites are described in the Mahabharata and other similarly ancient texts - it does set it apart from some of the younger pilgrimages which have had less time to build up popularity. * Vaishno Devi’s connections to Rama and to Kalki give this pilgrimage site holy significance and appeal to Vaishnavas as well as Shaktas. Namdev, a medieval Vaishnava saint, visited Vaishno Devi, further strengthening this inter-sectarian appeal. This sets it apart from the many pilgrimage sites which appeal to only one sect. It is also holy to Sikhs as well as Hindus, having supposedly been visited by Guru Nanak and Guru Gobind Singh. * Its surroundings are visually beautiful, nestled in the green, forested Trikuta Hills. Some of the other most popular pilgrimage sites in India stand out as also being nestled in green hills and/or dramatic mountains, being beside mighty rivers, etc. Many others are in the middle of busy (and often dirty) cities, or in deforested, flat, brown lands of no particular beauty. This may be a relevant factor. * It is far away from most Indians, way up in Jammu in the extreme north of the country. Perhaps this is actually a bonus for its popularity? Maybe pilgrims like to go somewhere a little farther from home? Similarly, once there you have to hike twelve miles and then squeeze through a narrow cave. Again this level of physical engagement, rather than simply driving right to the door of a temple, may be part of the appeal. * It’s a year-round, all-season pilgrimage site. Many Indian pilgrimages are supposed to be performed at certain times of year - but people may not be able to take time off work at that time, etc. If you want to perform a pilgrimage within a certain date range, many options may be closed, but Vaishno Devi is always open. Vaishno Devi is far from unique in this, but it may be a contributing factor. * Once a site becomes highly popular, it can snowball. Vaishno Devi’s sheer fame attracts more pilgrims, which further grows its fame. Also, on a very practical level, Vaishno Devi receives almost $16 million per year in donations. It can afford a big advertising budget, with feature films about Vaishno Devi going back to the 1970s, TV serials, etc. Most individual Indian pilgrimage sites don’t have such a media presence. But in the end, even the combination of all these factors is not all that unique. One could surely find various other pilgrimage sites in India that share many factors like these, and yet are not nearly as popular as Vaishno Devi. Having performed traditional pilgrimages in India myself, and talked with fellow pilgrims on the trails, I found that the above sorts of rationales are not what most Indian pilgrims think about. Rather, they think about Darshan - the holy presence in the temple. It is the experience of millions of pilgrims that not all sites have the same Darshan. Ultimately, I suspect the #1 factor that makes Vaishno Devi so popular is that its sheer palpable sacred power which devotees experience within their consciousness is simply greater than that of the vast majority of other pilgrimage sites. Jai Mata Di!

After those three, the exact order gets increasingly hard to determine, as precise figures on numbers of visitors become less reliable and more difficult to find. But here are some more of the most popular temples in India, not necessarily in order:

  • Guruvayurappan Temple in Guyuvayur, Kerala, dedicated to Lord Krishna. 6 to 10 million devotees visit annually, especially during its spectacular festivals.
  • Akshardham Temple in Delhi, with nearly ten million visitors per year - unsurprising given its convenient location in India’s capital city, and its spectacular size and architectural beauty. This temple is dedicated to the Guru Swaminarayan. I personally have visited it twice with different groups of people while in Delhi.
  • The next most popular temples in India are probably the Char Dham temples, the four great temples appointed by Adi Shankaracharya at the far east, south, west, and north of India. These four temples are the seats of the four lineages of Gurus descending from Adi Shankaracharya, each associated with one of the four Vedas, and together they form one of the most popular pilgrimages in India.
  • The pilgrimage starts with the eastern temple, Shri Jagannath Temple in Puri, Odisha, dedicated to Lord Krishna and His siblings Lord Balabhadra and Goddess Subhadra. It looks out to the east over the Bay of Bengal. This temple is best known for its annual and world-famous Ratha Yatra, when its three Deities ride through the city streets on gigantic and spectacular chariots amid crowds of thousands. It is also famous for its huge and majestic kitchen.
  • Next comes the southern temple, Ramanathaswamy Temple in on the small island of Rameshwaram, Tamil Nadu off the south coast of India, with 8.4 million visitors per year (probably a similar number to the other Char Dham temples). Despite the name, this temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. Lord Rama and his wife Sita landed here after Rama rescued Sita from the demon king of Lanka, and they along with Hanuman established the worship of Lord Shiva on the spot. It is one of the twelve Jyotirlingas.
  • Then comes the western temple, Dwarkadhish Temple (also called Jagat Temple) in Dwarka, Gujarat on the Arabian Sea, again dedicated to Lord Krishna, who had His holy abode here in person during His Avatarana on Earth.
  • Finally comes the northern temple, the beautiful Badrinath Temple in Chamoli, Uttarakhand, high in the cold and snowy Himalayas near the glacial source of the holy Alakananda river. This temple can be visited only from April to November due to heavy snows. It is dedicated to Vishnu in His form of Nara-Narayana or Badri Narayana. In addition to being the climax of the pan-Indian Char Dham Yatra, Badrinath Temple is also the climax of another Char Dham Yatra local to the Himalayas, the Chota Char Dham Yatra. It is also one of the 108 Divya Desams, temples dedicated to Lord Vishnu, renowned among saints even in the far south of India in ancient times. This holy valley is praised as a domain of great sages in ancient scriptures like the Bhagavata Mahapurana. I have visited this temple, and it is my personal favorite temple in India (so far, at least). I wrote this answer about it:
Devala Rees
· 8mo
What was the most supernatural experience you’ve had at a temple?
It was at the Badrinath Temple in Uttarakhand, India. First of all, two days in a row in that temple I sat down alone, with no one around, closed my eyes in meditation, and immediately experienced a timeless state of inner awareness with no idea of my external surroundings or how much time might be passing; indeed I had no concept of time at all. The next thing of which I was conscious was a feeling that I should ‘wake up’, so to speak. I did so and found that several hours had passed, a crowd of fellow devotees was literally physically pressed up against me without my notice, and a woman was tapping me (and everyone else) on the shoulder and saying it was time to go outside so the pujaris could prepare for upcoming ceremonies. Later, while attending evening Arati to Vishnu in the temple, during the loud and fast ringing of the bells and the waving of flames in ritual patterns before the Swayambhu Murti of Badri Narayana, I saw a vision in the flickering firelight. This was a vivid apparition overriding my physical sight, not something subtle. I saw faces of Vishnu - living, real faces, not carven or painted depictions, and not just one, but another and another, flashing in rapid succession. A palpable energy shot up my spine like a spike, the most powerfully I had ever felt. I was definitely gasping and crying, mostly in a very good way, though it wasn’t entirely comfortable. My vision of the faces coalesced such that I saw all the faces at once, outspread in a sweeping gallery almost, though they were all atop one vast body. Many of them were beautiful, smiling, some feminine (possibly as many as were masculine), shining with light; but many others were quite monstrous in appearance, glaring fiercely (not necessarily at me, but in various directions) and spitting sickly-looking fire or gnashing meat between their fangs. It felt in a way that they were more than faces, that they somehow encapsulated the phenomena of the universe. That vision ended as the pujaris carried the Arati flames over to the devotees (including me), and we took blessings from them. Just as I was finishing doing so, Vishnu laid His hand on my right shoulder. I’m not claiming objective reality of this; certainly the people sitting right next to me didn’t seem to see anything; but it was my experience. I felt it at least as physically as any other sensation. His hand was so hot that any more heat would’ve burned me; it felt like it should’ve scorched my clothes, yet it felt extremely pleasurable. His heat spread through my body in a kind of wave, like a thick, steaming, brothy nectar that tasted like Home. Then the pujaris performed Vishnu Sahasranama and Sahasranamavali. During that long chant (maybe half an hour or so) I actually had one of the most privately meaningful spiritual experiences of my life, but I think I should keep that part to myself for now.
  • About four million pilgrims perform the Chota Char Dham Yatra per year (I was among them in 2010), so I will mention the other three temples of this pilgrimage here. The aforementioned Badrinath is the last. The first is Yamunotri Temple in Uttarkashi district, Uttarakhand, dedicated to the Goddess Yamuna. High in the harsh conditions of the Himalayas, this temple has been repeatedly damaged by natural disasters and rebuilt, and can only be reached on foot, not by roads. Like all of the Chota Char Dham temples, it cannot be visited during the long, harsh Himalayan winter (which includes much of spring and fall as well - the temple is open from Akshaya Tritiya until Diwali).
  • Next comes Gangotri Temple, also in Uttarkashi disrict, Uttarakhand, dedicated to the Goddess Ganga. This temple stands on the spot where Raja Bhagiratha performed rigorous penance for many years to convince Mother Ganga to descend from Heaven to Earth to release his ancestors from a curse, and to bless the land with Her many virtues. So she asked him to persuade Lord Shiva to catch Her so that Her impact wouldn’t break the Earth. Bhagiratha prayed to Shiva, and He agreed to catch Mother Ganga in the twisted locks of His hair, and release Her in a gradual and manageable flow. Originally this temple was right at the Ganga’s glacial source, but with climate change the glacier has retreated some 18 kms further up the mountain, and is now a holy trek from the temple. I personally love Gangotri so much I recently returned to it for a second visit.
  • Then comes Kedarnath Temple in Rudraprayag district, Uttarakhand, a holy abode of Shiva built by the Pandavas to atone for their sins during the Mahabharata, and restored by Adi Shankaracharya. To reach it requires a steep 14 km trek (except for a wealthy few who now take a helicopter!), up into a beautiful panorama of majestic glaciers and snow-clad peaks (much like all the Chota Char Dham sites). It is another of the aforementioned twelve Jyotirlinga temples.
  • Shri Saibaba Samadhi Temple in Shirdi, Maharashtra receives well over 7.3 million pilgrims per year. It is the tomb of the renowned Saint Sai Baba of Shirdi.
  • Palini Murugan Temple in Tamil Nadu, dedicated to Lord Murugan, receives over 7 million pilgrims per year. It is the most popular of the Six Abodes of Murugan.
  • The nearby Tiruchendur temple, also dedicated primarily to Lord Murugan, receives a similar number of pilgrims.
  • Returning to the the Himalayan theme, another of the most popular temples in India is Amarnath Cave Temple in Kashmir, which received as many as 6.3 million pilgrims in its most popular year. It is dedicated to Shiva in His form as Lord Amarnath, a large Shiva Linga made of solid ice. Engulfed in the snow-clad mountains, it is only accessible from June to August, and even then only via a five-day trek with uncertain weather.
  • Meenakshi Temple in Madurai, Tamil Nadu receives as many as six million annual pilgrims by some estimates. This temple is dedicated to the Goddess Meenakshi, and renowned for its wonderful architecture.
  • Attukal Bhagavathy Temple near the heart of the city of Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala, dedicated to the Goddess Kannaki Bhadrakali, has a major annual women’s festival, the Attukal Pongal festival. The number of women who attend this festival has reached as high as 4.9 million. The Goddesses Maha Saraswati, Maha Lakshmi, and Maha Kali are all worshipped here.
  • Somnath Temple in Prabhas Kshetra, Saurashtra, Gujarat is another of the most revered twelve Jyotirlinga temples, praised in ancient scriptures like Shiva Mahapurana and Skanda Mahapurana. It receives 4.5 million annual pilgrims. It is said that the Moon God Soma built the original Somnath Temple to thank Lord Shiva for curing him of an ancient curse. It is also near the site where Lord Krishna ended His mortal life in this world.
  • Mahabodhi Mahavira Temple in Bodh Gaya, Bihar receives four million pilgrims per year, mostly Buddhists. It was built by the famous King Ashoka to mark the auspicious site where Siddhartha Gautama attained Enlightenment and became a Buddha. The temple also carefully preserves the direct line of descendants of the original Bodhi Tree, the tree under which Siddhartha Gautama attained Enlightenment.
  • Sabarimala Temple on a hilltop in the Western Ghats in Pathanamthitta District, Kerala receives 3.2 million pilgrims per year. It is dedicated to Lord Ayyappa. It is reached by a long trek on foot, during a rather narrow window of the year, as the temple is closed to visitors at all other times.
  • Kandariya Mahadeva Temple in Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh receives 2.79 million visitors per year, many of whom also visit some of the 19 other temples in the complex. These temples are famous for their explicit erotic carvings, and host the annual Khajuraho Dance Festival.
  • Kamakhya Temple, nestled in the Blue Hill in Guwahati, Assam, receives 2.5 million pilgrims per year. Dedicated to the Goddess Kamru Kamakhya, this temple is the first and foremost of the fifty-one great Shakti Peethas or primary Shakti temples, and it is said to be the very birthplace of Shakta Tantra. This incredibly sacred temple houses the Yoni of the Goddess Sati. I wrote this answer about it:
Devala Rees
· Jan 17
What’s so special about Maa Kamakhya Teerth? Why is it glorified so profoundly in Devi Maha Bhagavat Puran?
Kamakhya Teertha is one of the most special and sacred sites in all of Shakta Dharma. Of the fifty-one Maha Shakti Peethas across south Asia, Kamakhya Teertha is the most popular and renowned; it is considered the first and foremost of them, and the very birthplace of Shakta Tantra. It receives 2.5 million pilgrims per year. The sacred story of the Shakti Peethas goes that upon the death of the ancient Goddess Sati, Her body was shredded into many pieces (fifty-one main pieces) that were scattered across South Asia. Where each body part fell, a temple was raised to worship Her there. Kamakhya Teertha is the holy site where the Goddess’s Yoni (vagina) fell to Earth. But this was no coincidence, for according to the Kalika Purana, the site that became Kamakhya Teertha, on the beautiful Blue Hill (Nilachala or Nila Parvata) of Assam, was a spot where Sati used to go in secret to satisfy her amour with Shiva, and so her Yoni was drawn back to this site as if by magnetic attraction. The name of the Goddess, Kamru Kamakhya, shows that her Yoni is seen primarily as an organ of Her sexual pleasure, and only secondarily for reproductive purposes. Indeed Kamakhya is considered to be the very embodiment of Kama or pleasure. The Goddess’s intense desire and pleasure is understood in a profound mystical sense by the Tantrik masters, referring to Her overwhelming longing, even lust, to unite in ecstatic union with the pure consciousness or Shiva-Tattwa, including the consciousness of Her devotees who merge into Her through the fulfillment of the path of Maha Tantra and experience the infinite bliss of the Divine Union. Thus Kamakhya Teertha is seen as the place on Earth where the Divine most intently longs to unite with devotees. She is worshipped there in the form of an ancient stone Yoni. To this day, Kamakhya Teertha is one of the most revered centers of Tantrik practices, mysticism, and sorcery. It unites both Dakshinachara (Right-Handed) and Vamachara (Left-Handed) Tantra in its worship customs, and hosts the largest festival assembly of Tantriks in the world, the annual Ambubachi or Ambuvasi Mela. Tantriks from far and wide, and from far disparate schools of Tantra, return here to the birthplace of their traditions once a year to worship Kamru Kamakhya together. She is worshipped both with bloody animal sacrifices and other Vamachara rites, as well as the Sattwik and sanitary rites of the Dakshina path. Specifically this festival celebrates the menstruation of the Goddess as an intensely sacred event, and the whole area is awash with the holy power of Her blood. A wet red cloth, symbolizing the Goddess’s used menstrual pad, is passed around to visitors as sacred Prasad, as well as red-colored water to drink. Kāmākhye Varade Devī Nīla Parvata Vāsinī Twaṁ Devī Jagataṁ Mātā Yonimudre Namostute! (Oh Goddess Kamakhya, boon-giver, dweller on the Blue Hill, Thou, O Goddess, art the Mother of the World. I bow to Thee in the form of the Yoni!)

I could keep on going indefinitely, but those are some of the most popular temples in India.

Rohit Monga

What makes Hindu temples stunning?

There are many reasons. For each person, the temple serves a specific purpose.

  • For a devotee who performs deity worship at home, some of the 16 upacharas require enormous efforts to concentrate and meditate. The big idol in the temple solves that and makes it easy for eyes.
  • For religious people, it works as place of God where their prayers/requests are heard/accepted.
  • For cultural people, it works as a opportunity to express their cultural talent. For example, trained singers/dancers perform in the temple premises or expression of arts/sculpture on the walls/gopuram etc.
  • For a society, it works as

There are many reasons. For each person, the temple serves a specific purpose.

  • For a devotee who performs deity worship at home, some of the 16 upacharas require enormous efforts to concentrate and meditate. The big idol in the temple solves that and makes it easy for eyes.
  • For religious people, it works as place of God where their prayers/requests are heard/accepted.
  • For cultural people, it works as a opportunity to express their cultural talent. For example, trained singers/dancers perform in the temple premises or expression of arts/sculpture on the walls/gopuram etc.
  • For a society, it works as people gathering forgetting all the differences and being as God’s own children spreading love and caring.
  • For students, it works as an educational institution. All Siva temples have to have a mandatory sanskrit grammar mandapa where grammar was taught.
  • For poor, it works as a place where they are fed daily without having to beg or struggle for food.
  • For service oriented, it works as a great opportunity to service God and Mankind together.

Having so many facets to one location is always stunning, to say the least. Hope this helps. God bless!
